ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: lots of new ASL vocab, a greater comfort level with ASL, and d/Deaf history

I learned more essential signs, Deaf history events, and storytelling skills. I feel more comfortable carrying out conservations, translating stories and poems, and describing spaces. I also enjoyed learning more about Deaf historical figures and feel more knowledgable about important events and figures in Deaf culture.
Further advancing upon ASL knowledge learned in ASL 110 and 120
I learned a lot more ASL vocabulary, grammar, and conversation techniques. I also learned a lot about deaf culture and how deaf people have adapted to society's pressures to fit in.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: ANDREW, the ASL community at Yale, getting to just talk about our days and everything in class, the feedback, the welcoming environment

The strengths of this course is the environment promoted by the teachers. I truly felt able to learn and grow without a fear of being judged or graded poorly if I make mistakes. I was given the opportunity to learn from my mistakes through feedback and it allowed me to improve over the semester. 

There are no weaknesses I can think of as I truly enjoyed this course.

Strengths: Engaging, professor really cares about his students, lots of fun games, lots of time dedicated to review
Weaknesses: It's hard to review vocabulary while not in class because the slides usually just show pictures, not words (and not the signs that go with them)

Every class is so much fun and engaging. At the l3 level, I feel pretty comfortable having conversations in ASL so the group work and the turn and talking we do is so much fun. I think the journals are somewhat meaningless and don't help with learning ASL much. However, the textbook is very helpful and is really helpful in learning how to interpret finger spelling and different people's unique style of signing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES!!! Take ASL if you can

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning a new language or learning about Deaf culture. ASL is a beautiful language that I truly believe many can benefit from learning. In addition, the ASL community at Yale has been very rewarding to be a part of.

Yes. ASL is a great language to take at Yale, and it's especially great with Andrew. The program is relatively new, so the professors are still learning and trying new things with the program, but you can tell they're really passionate about it and building a community.
Yes, I will always recommend to other students that they take ASL. It has by far been my favorite class at Yale, and I will continue taking ASL until I run out of classes to take.

Yes absolutely. ASL is the best! It's gratifying and fun to learn and a skill that will be helpful when you least expect it. Also, the deaf world is so vibrant and wonderful to be a part of. Deaf humor is so sarcastic and witty. It's always fascinating to learn how to be funny in a new language and ASL is no different.

Of course! ASL has been one of the most rewarding, challenging, and fun aspects of my experience here at Yale. The professors are amazing and undoubtedly one of the best parts of the program. The curriculum not only teaches you about a language, but about Deaf culture and community. I recommend ASL to every person I can.
